title: A geologist, a former SpaceX launch director and a commercial astronaut; meet NASA’s 10 new astronaut candidates
summary: The cohort of ten women and men will train for the next two years to become eligible for mission assignments to low Earth orbit and beyond. This is the first astronaut candidate class to consist of more women than men.
detailed_news: The collection of ten women and men from across the United States were selected from more than 8,000 applications submitted. They represent the 24th astronaut candidate (ASCAN) class picked by NASA. Among the six women in this group is Anna Menon, the first astronaut candidate in history who has flown in orbital space prior to being selected as a NASA astronaut. NASA has added extra safeguards to the agency’s standard pre-launch quarantine protocol to protect astronauts Bob Behnken and Doug Hurley from the coronavirus and other contagions. Ground controllers have lost contact with two briefcase-sized CubeSats beyond Mars, NASA said Tuesday.

SDA is building out a low Earth orbit (LEO) mesh network for military communications. The Transport Layer satellites will provide beyond line-of-sight connectivity. title: Launch Roundup: Kuiper, Starlink, IMAP headline launch manifest
summary:
A busy slate of launches is planned for the last full week of September, including…
The post Launch Roundup: Kuiper, Starlink, IMAP headline launch manifest appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: A busy slate of launches is planned for the last full week of September, including flights for two major low-Earth orbit broadband constellations. China and Rocket Lab are also planning flights, with Electron set to fly two suborbital hypersonic research missions from Wallops Island, Virginia. The United Launch Alliance (ULA) is planning to fly an Atlas V 551 on the KA-03 mission for the Amazon Kuiper constellation, while SpaceX is preparing to fly four Falcon 9 Starlink missions. The Jielong 3 rocket is capable of flying up to 1,600 kg to a 500 km altitude. The rocket will carry the Jili (Geely) Constellation 06 satellites A through K. The Geely communications satellite constellation is designed to offer coverage for the Internet of Things. The IMAP spacecraft will study the boundary between the heliosphere and interstellar space. The United Launch Alliance has scheduled its third Atlas V flight of the year for Thursday, Sept. 25. Amazon is racing to launch as many Kuiper satellites as possible before a July 2026 deadline. China is planning to fly a Chang Zheng 2D (CZ-2D) on Friday, September 26, at 17:20 UTC. The third Starlink launch of this week is scheduled for Sunday, Sept. 28 at 3:30 AM EDT (07:30 UTC) from SLC-40 at the CCSFS. The rocket will take a northeast trajectory and will fly a batch of Starlink v2 Mini satellites to low-Earth orbit inclined 53.16 degrees to the Equator. This is the ninth CZ-6 series launch of 2025.

title: NASA Chooses 10 New Astronaut Candidates
summary: NASA introduced its 24th class of astronauts today, six women and four men. It is the first astronaut class with more women than men and the first with anyone who […]
detailed_news: NASA introduced its 24th class of astronauts today, six women and four men. It is the first astronaut class with more women than men and the first with anyone who already has made an orbital spaceflight. The 10 astronaut candidates will train for two years before becoming eligible for NASA missions to Earth orbit, the Moon and beyond. The other ASCANs are equally impressive as detailed in NASA’s press release. Ben Bailey is a U.S. Naval Test Pilot School graduate with more than 2,000 flight hours in more than 30 different rotary and fixed-wing aircraft. His first spaceflight is scheduled for next year on Soyuz MS-29. Anna Menon, 39, is from Houston and earned her bachelor’s degree from Texas Christian University. Imelda Muller, 34, considers Copake Falls, New York, her hometown. Erin Overcash is a former Marine Corps AH-1 attack helicopter pilot and experimental test pilot.

detailed_news: Air Force Secretary Troy Meink likens today's threats to the Sputnik shock of 1957. He warns that the United States risks falling behind adversaries, particularly China. Meink says he is increasingly worried about the services' pace of innovation. He stressed that the U.S. continues to field “the best trained force in the world” Enter the code we sent to your email. detailed_news: NASA announced its newest class of astronauts Sept. 22. The six women and four men represent NASA’s first astronaut class with more women than men. The class includes scientists, engineers and pilots, with experience ranging from flying military aircraft in combat to working on the Curiosity Mars rover. NASA’s Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel raised similar concerns at a Sept. 19 meeting. “I’ll be damned if the Chinese beat NASA, or beat America, back to the moon. We’re going to win,” Sean Duffy said. Duffy did not directly address recent criticism of Artemis.

Volunteers from NASA’s Open Science Data Repository Analysis Working Groups (OSDR-AWG) are working together to analyze data on astronaut health. The AWGs examine biomedical data from NASA missions and space experiments collected in the NASA Open Science data Repository.

title: NASA Safety Panel Estimates Significant Delays for Starship HLS
summary: NASA’s Aerospace Safety Advisory panel is warning that SpaceX’s Starship Human Landing System (HLS) could be “years late” for the Artemis III mission that is supposed to take place in […]
detailed_news: NASA’s Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel is warning that SpaceX's Starship Human Landing System (HLS) could be “years late” for the Artemis III mission that is supposed to take place in mid-2027. The assessment comes after three ASAP members visited SpaceX's Starbase facility in Boca Chica, TX and met with top SpaceX officials. While they were quite impressed with SpaceX's manufacturing and operations tempo, they nonetheless found the schedule for HLS is “significantly challenged.  ASAP has been recommending since 2023 that NASA reevaluate the “high number of individual risks and mission firsts” associated with Artemis III. ASAP was created by Congress in 1968 following the 1967 Apollo 1 tragedy that killed NASA astronauts Virgil “Gus” Grissom, Ed White, and Roger Chaffee.

title: XRISM observes windy neutron star, Chandra studies a luminous quasar
summary:
Using the joint Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA), European Space Agency (ESA), and NASA X-Ray…
The post XRISM observes windy neutron star, Chandra studies a luminous quasar appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Using the joint Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA), European Space Agency (ESA), and NASA X-Ray Imaging and Spectroscopy Mission (XRISM), scientists uncovered a dense but surprisingly slow wind coming from a neutron star. Another team used NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory to study an ancient supermassive black hole growing at extreme rates. When the neutron star lit up, it exceeded its so-called Eddington limit. As matter falls into the object, it releases energy, and with more matter falling in, the amount of energy released increases as well. This energy pushes back on the material falling in and capping the rate at which matter can fall in. The intense radiation at the EdDington limit blows away the material surrounding the neutronstar, creating a cosmic wind. This phenomenon is also observed around supermassive black holes. RACS J0320−35 might hint at the nature of recently discovered “little red dots” found scattered throughout the early universe. These dots first showed up in 2022, in some of the first observations from the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) Astronomers have since been looking for an explanation.

title: What’s Happening in Space Policy September 21-27, 2025
summary: Here is SpacePolicyOnline.com’s list of space policy events for the week of September 21-27, 2025 and any insight we can offer about them. The House and Senate are in recess […]
detailed_news: The House and Senate are in recess this week except for pro forma sessions. NASA begins a three-day human spaceflight extravaganza at Johnson Space Center. Washington Post reporter Christian Davenport will talk about his new book at two events in D.C. this week. On Friday, the House passed a Republican version of a Continuing Resolution (CR) that would keep the government open through November 21. All but one Democrat opposed it, and all but two Republicans supported it. The Senate then defeated that bill as well as a Democratic alternative (through October 31) that insists on including a provision extending Affordable Health Care premium subsidies. Both votes were on largely partisan lines.

title: Shutdown Showdown September 2025: The State of Play 10 Days Out
summary: Unless Congress and the President can reach agreement in the next 10 days, there will be a government shutdown on October 1. Both sides say they do not want that […]
detailed_news: Congress has not passed the FY2026 appropriations bills needed to fund the government when the new fiscal year begins on October 1. A Continuing Resolution is needed to keep the government open until the 12 regular appropriations bills are signed into law. Agencies typically are kept at their current funding levels under a CR and new programs cannot begin nor existing programs terminated. The rocket will head away from Florida’s Space Coast on a north-easterly trajectory. Spaceflight Now will have live coverage beginning about an hour prior to liftoff.

title: Ship 38 on Pad 1 for Static Fire testing as Masseys rebuild continues
summary:
As SpaceX presses on with attempts to complete static fire testing with Ship 38 ahead…
The post Ship 38 on Pad 1 for Static Fire testing as Masseys rebuild continues appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Following the anomaly with Ship 36, SpaceX has made significant progress in rebuilding the test stand. Crews have nearly rebuilt the entire Methane tank farm, upgrading storage capacity with the addition of a new horizontal tank. SpaceX is also using its own valve skids for both the Liquid Oxygen (LOX) and Liquid Methane (LCH4) sides of the tank farm. SpaceX has rolled test tank B18.3 out to Masseys. This test tank is designed to evaluate the hot stage truss, new grid fin cavities, and the rest of the forward section of the Block 3 booster. Gigabay construction has made significant progress, with crews completing seven concrete pours so far. Ship 38 has had two aborted attempts at a static fire. SpaceX needs permission to build on the wetlands, tidal flats, and uplands that they own south of the current launch site. To fly Block 3 and later from that location, SpaceX must upgrade the pad to the newer design. SpaceX is expected to have the required land swap credits by early 2026.

The FROG-H vehicle had been expected to complete initial test flights in early 2025. In addition to FROG, CNES is also working on the Callisto reusable rocket programme.

VIPER will search for water ice at the lunar south pole, including in permanently shadowed craters. In July 2024, NASA said it would cancel VIPER , citing cost overruns. title: The Ancient Mars Variety Show
summary: Written by Melissa Rice, Professor of Planetary Science at Western Washington University Perseverance accomplished something unusual this week: abrading two dramatically different rocks within the span of a few days. While exploring the Vernodden area along Jezero crater’s rim, the rover has been studying what might be “megablocks,” a variety of ancient crustal materials with […]
detailed_news: The Mars Perseverance rover abraded two dramatically different rocks within the span of a few days. While exploring the Vernodden area along Jezero crater's rim, the rover has been studying what might be "megablocks" The ancient fragments can help the Science Team reconstruct the complex geological processes that shaped early Mars billions of years ago.

title: VIPER Might Have A New Ride to the Moon on Blue Origin
summary: NASA’s much-anticipated but imperiled VIPER lunar rover got some good news today. More than a year after NASA announced it was terminating the mission even though the rover is completely […]
detailed_news: NASA awarded a contract to Blue Origin to take initial steps that, if successful, could lead to VIPER flying on Blue Origin’s Blue Moon MK1 lander. VIPER is an option and NASA won’t decide whether to exercise that option until step one is completed. Astrobotic had been awarded a fixed price contract of $323 million to deliver VIPER to the lunar surface through CLPS. The lunar science community and Congress reacted negatively to the decision and NASA decided to issue a call for expressions of interest by organizations that might want to take over the project. Astrobotic said in an emailed statement today they had decided not to submit a bid.

title: Amid budget uncertainty, NASA gets some good news: Use House funding levels
summary: The House budget still cuts science at NASA, but not as deeply as the White House sought.
detailed_news: Congress has not passed a final budget for fiscal year 2026, which begins on October 1. The White House proposed significant cuts to NASA's budget. The House budget proposes to keep funding levels nearly identical to the current fiscal year. This does not support full funding for NASA's science portfolio, but is far more beneficial than the cuts sought by the White House.

title: After a very slow start, Europe’s reusable rocket program shows signs of life
summary: Although Themis is making progress, the program is several years behind schedule.
detailed_news: Themis is a prototype rocket that will test various landing technologies. Low-altitude hop tests, a precursor for developing a rocket's first stage that can vertically land after an orbital launch, could start late this year or early next. Although Themis is making progress, the program is several years behind schedule.

title: NASA Selects Blue Origin to Deliver VIPER Rover to Moon’s South Pole
summary: As part of the agency’s Artemis campaign, NASA has awarded Blue Origin of Kent, Washington, a CLPS (Commercial Lunar Payload Services) task order with an option to deliver a rover to the Moon’s South Pole region. NASA’s VIPER (Volatiles Investigating Polar Exploration Rover) will search for volatile resources, such as ice, on the lunar surface […]
detailed_news: NASA has awarded Blue Origin of Kent, Washington, a CLPS task order with an option to deliver a rover to the Moon’s South Pole region. VIPER (Volatiles Investigating Polar Exploration Rover) will search for volatile resources, such as ice, on the lunar surface. The VIPER rover will study the distribution and origin of volatiles across the solar system. It will also help us better understand the processes that have shaped our space environment. Through CLPS, American companies continue to demonstrate leadership in commercial space advancing capabilities and accomplishing NASA’s goal for a commercial lunar economy.

Themis programme is being funded by the European Space Agency and the European Union.

title: American leadership at Apophis

summary:
We are fewer than four years away from what may be the most significant near-Earth asteroid event of the 21st century. On April 13, 2029, the asteroid Apophis — named for the Egyptian god of chaos — will pass so close to Earth that it will be visible to the naked eye across much of […]

Despite the failure to get to orbit, Isar considers the first Spectrum launch a successful test flight. The company is working toward a second flight of Spectrum, which will take place "as soon as possible" Northrop Grumman inked a contract with SpaceX for three Falcon 9 launches. Launch companies are reiterating plans to sharply increase flight rates. United Launch Alliance projected 20 launches in 2025 between the Atlas 5 and Vulcan Centaur. title: Hubble Images Celestial Cigar’s Smoldering Heart

detailed_news: Messier 82 (M82) is 12 million light-years away in the constellation Ursa Major (the Great Bear) The galaxy forms stars 10 times faster than the Milky Way. The intense starbirth period that grips this galaxy gave rise to super star clusters in the galaxy’s heart.
